description: From Middle English graithen, greithen, graiden, grathen, from Old Norse greiða (“to make ready, prepare, arrange, disentangle”), from Proto-Germanic *garaidijaną (“to prepare, put in order”). Cognate with Old English ġerǣdan (“to arrange, dispose, order, provide for, harness”), Gothic 𐌲𐌰𐍂𐌰𐌹𐌳𐌾𐌰𐌽 (garaidjan, “to enjoin”).

verbs.description: graith (third-person singular simple present graiths, present participle graithing, simple past and past participle graithed)

entries.meaning: (obsolete outside Scotland) To make ready; prepare; put in order; make fit for use.
examples: Gowden graith'd his horse before, and siller shod behind  […]

entries.meaning: (obsolete outside dialects, chiefly UK) To dress (someone or oneself) or be dressed.
examples: At fairs he play'd before the spearmen, All gaily graithed in their gear-men.

description: From Middle English graith, graythe, greithe, from Old Norse greiði (“preparation, arrangement”), from Proto-Germanic *garaidiją (“apparatus, gadget”). Cognate with Icelandic greiðe, greiði (“preparation, arrangement, order, hospitality”), Faroese greiði (“requisite articles”), Norwegian greida (“implements, tackle”), Norwegian greide (“harness”).

examples: Is your razor in good graith? (B.K.)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Accoutrements: clothes, materials, equipment, furniture, etc.
examples: Item, to James Homel, to buy graith for the King's vellum doublet, 0[L.] 10[s.] 0[d.]
